Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: High Speed Reactive Extrusion for Stabilized and Toughened Renewable Polymer Blends and Copolymers

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program grant funds a study of the processing behavior and life cycle of renewably-sourced plastics, and works to inspire female students to proactively pursue engineering careers. High-speed extrusion coupled with interfacial reaction has the potential to intimately blend dissimilar polymers in order to access the entire range of combinatorial properties. The research will characterize the effects of this novel process on blend microstructure and correlate bulk properties to processing parameters. Creation of a predictive model of the processing rheology will enable expansion to other polymer blends, including recycled plastics. The research will also be used as a catalyst for broadening participation of women in engineering by bringing student-run demonstrations of career options to local vocational and traditional high school programs. A multimedia informational public service website and a module on climate change and sustainability for freshman courses will demystify environmental sustainability and the plastics industry.

This work will probe the intersection of renewable materials and cutting-edge processing strategies to discover new techniques for reinforcement of biobased plastics. As a result of this research the stability and properties of bio-based polymers will be modified to create robust plastics that can be used in place of conventional fossil-derived polymers in durable goods applications. The use of high shear also has the potential to reduce energy consumption in extrusion processes. Structure-properties-processing relationships will be determined for the polymer blends. A substantial experiential learning effort will be launched to broaden participation of women in engineering and to expand visibility of the engineering profession at the critical high school level, including student populations with less exposure to higher education options. These activities will establish mentoring relationships and early positive experiences on several levels of the educational pipeline, while improving science literacy and communication.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this NSF CAREER award were to build fundamental understanding of energy-efficient processing and life cycle for renewable polymers, to educate students and the public about sustainable plastics technology, and to support the persistence of women in the engineering profession. In pursuit of these goals, the Principle Investigator built a research program centered on ultra-high speed twin-screw extrusion of biobased polymers that explored methods to improve their physical properties, while emphasizing the cross-disciplinary aspects of polymer sustainability and serving as a champion of women in STEM fields.

The first outcome of the extrusion processing research was an enhanced understanding of the separate mechanical and thermal effects of extreme shear on polymer melts. These effects were modeled for single-polymer processing and expanded to both nanocomposites and polymer-polymer blends. The second outcome was understanding of the process variables that govern structure and properties of two biobased polymer blends: poly(lactic acid)/polyamide-11 and poly(butylene succinate)/poly(propylene carbonate). The third technical outcome was knowledge on efficacy of two methods to compatibilize these immiscible blends: addition of a graft compatibilizer and in situ reaction between the two polymers at the interface.  These three outcomes have contributed to a greater understanding of how to modify and process biobased polymers using energy-efficient advanced manufacturing methods.

This project contributed to two summer programs designed to broaden participation in engineering. The College of Engineering annually hosts 50 -100 high school-age students for a weeklong Summer School on Engineering Sustainability. The PI's research group led an interactive project on plastics recycling as part of the summer camp. Students learned about the technical, economic and human behavior challenges associated with plastics recycling, and completed an experimental research project looking at the effects of recycled content in packaging properties. The campus Climate Change Initiative hosts 20 - 30 K-12 teachers for a workshop on teaching climate science, engineering politics and social issues. The PI developed a module on renewable energy engineering solutions and provided teaching activities and tools to the groups of educators.

Both the objectives of communicating science to the public and of educating students in effective communication of technical topics were achieved through development of a website, www.plasticsfacts.com, designed to separate fact from fiction on the topic of polymer sustainability. The PI organized the site around three themes: resource sustainability of plastics raw materials, plastics lifecycle issues, and health and toxicity concerns of plastics. Articles from the popular press were posted to the site and commentary provided on the scientific myth or fact presented in the articles. In addition, the site hosts a blog to which undergraduate and graduate students contribute their own articles on important contemporary topics on plastics sustainability such as the ban on recycling imports in China and the concerns around microplastics in the oceans. These activities have been successful in teaching and communicating on these important issues, as determined by anecdotal feedback from student authors and website hit counts and comments.

The research was disseminated to academic audiences through twelve peer-reviewed publications in high quality journals in the field of polymer science and engineering. At least fourteen presentations at national and international conferences communicated results from the research to academicians and industry. Three Ph.D. students successfully defended their dissertations on high-speed extrusion as part of this project. Six undergraduate research assistants were also funded through this work and received technical and professional development training through their involvement with the group. This CAREER project has had impact on the career of the principle investigator, education of students in her group and beyond, the field of polymer science and engineering, and processing for a sustainable future.

Modified by: Margaret Sobkowiczkline
